(cradling a corded phone) Yeah, OK. I appreciate it, Walter. His wife and college sweetheart LEE, wipes an eye and hol his arm. He makes meaningful eye contact with BILL DIXON. Nearby are his son and daughter, JOHN and ANDREA.

The team moves through heartbroken supporters offering ad libbed, “Don't leave... stay in it...” A couple secret service agents push through as PHOTO FLASHES POP. Wilson continues to remind about policy.

(struggling) Come on, clear a path...
(to Hart) And Perestroika.

(to Wilson) Homeless and Russians, got it. Suddenly, COMMOTION. A woman screams. The secret service agents RUSH at Hart, pushing him back towards the suite.
What the fuck is -- Other agents converge on a man. For a moment, we see an A WITH A GUN being held up in the air.
Active shooter... Active shooter...
Oh God! What? The agents move like a scrum, pushing them back into... INT. VIP SUITE, ST. FRANCIS HOTEL. CONTINUOUS. Hart is pulled into a corner. An agent hovering over him.
Redwood is secure.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 6. We hear reports coming in over the walkie talkies as the shares looks with each other. Stunned.
Gary.... Gary?! They all look over at Hart. The secret service agent step away to reveal him doubled over, clutching his side.
Senator?!
We need a paramedic in the suite. Lee gets down on her knees to help, but Hart rears up LAUGHING hysterically, barely able to breathe.
Gary!! But he can’t stop laughing. After a long beat...
Who shoots the loser?
Hart, tie loosened, still laughing. In an image unfamilia for anyone today, Hart is drinking with his PRESS BUDDIES JACK GERMOND (The Sun) DAVID BRODER (The Post) IRA WYMAN.
Maybe he didn’t like your jobs plan, either.
We've been through that. It’s a good plan... It was a good plan. Reveal we are watching from another table, over the shoul of a younger generation of reporters.
Did anyone find out this guy’s reasons?
Yeah, they found a photo of you in his wife’s purse. Off laughter, we move to the Kids Table. ALAN WEINBERG, A MCDANIEL, DAVID AXELROD drinking cheap beer.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 7.
You really want to follow Mondale around for another six months?
My apartment is grim. I'll take the free meals.
Yeah, that’s how I feel about my boyfriend. BOB WOODWARD stops by the big boys table.
Holy shit, look, it’s Woodward.
Think he still comes into the newsroom?
I heard he doesn’t take a salary.
Doesn't need to. Have you seen his house?
Have you? We find Hart and Woodward now at the bar sharing whiskeys
... She’d have won you New Jersey if you hadn’t made that dumbass crack about the water.
No one’s got a sense of humor anymore.
Fuck ‘em if they can’t take a joke. (beat while he drinks) How's Lee doing?
She needs a rest.
Mondale did you a favor. Reagan's going to crush him.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17)
Maybe. Probably.
You'll have an open road in ‘88.
‘88... right.
Next time, they’re going to want the one thing you won't give.
What’s that?
Everything else.
Right.

And then BLACK. We hear a woman crying. TITLE SLIDE: WASHINGTON. 1987. INT. BEDROOM, GEORGETOWN. EARLY MORNING. Tammy Faye Bakker cries through runny mascara on “Charges expected in Bakker Family Scandal" The room is dark, but we find Gary’s legs on the bed. He’s pulling on his trademark COWBOY BOOTS.
... And so I always say, ‘Lord, I trust you with me.' Gary stands and leaves.

edge of his 1 swing.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 9.

Genetics. Swing back to Dixon building with steam withe volunteers.

So, when you're tired and your feet hurt and your hands are freezing because you’ve been knocking on doors in Nashua for twelve straight hours. When you miss your boyfriends and girlfriends, your kids. When you’re tired of eating leftovers because we don’t pay you jack shit, you think about the opportunity we have right now, and the cost to this great country if we squander it. The future of this country is in your hands. That’s no exaggeration. It’s in your hands. Hold it carefully. INT. THE WASHINGTON POST NEWSROOM. CONTINUOUS. The newsroom’s humming as Hart’s debate continues on TV. BEN BRADLEE’s office, where the legendary editor, seated behind his desk with Watergate-era photos behind him, is meeting with about 7 editors and reporters. In the room are: ANN DEVROY (30s, the political editor), DAVID BRODER (50s, the chief political correspondent), BO WOODWARD (40s, reporter of Watergate fame), BOB KAISER (4 national editor), and AJ PARKER from earlier.

Gore's looking at it.  Al Gore? Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 12.

Governor of Massachusetts.
Du-ka-kis. That's not going to look good on a campaign poster.
Add a “K". He could win the South. Bradlee watches Hart on TV for a moment. Parker notices.

Twelve? Jesus. Woodward, you know the guy. What do you think?
Gary Hart? He could win it. I mean, he’s got the hair.
How many points you think the hair is worth?
Six points. Four if it’s windy. Laughter, as we hear from the TV...  Applause. Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 13.
I think it's a little lofty for Senator Hart to be discussing our grand future without crediting President Reagan with the reforms we're seeing in the Soviet Union.

We didn't bankrupt the Soviets. Communism bankrupted itself, morally and economically. You don't get credit for kicking down a door that's already open. Hart smiles at Dole, who kind of smiles back. There’s genuine camaraderie amongst these men. INT. HART CAMPAIGN OFFICE, DENVER. CONTINUOUS. The campaign team sits in folding chairs.
Ribbon-cutting at the end of the week, and then a run-through of the grand announcement, six thousand feet above sea level, at Red Rocks.
Has anyone been able to move him off this weird mountain man thing?
He’s entrenched.
Technically, he can’t be entrenched if he’s on top of a mountain.

And elevators.
Has anyone told him we can’t drop balloons from a mountain?
Maybe we can rent a plane.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 14. Wilson continues to watch Hart on TV, enamored.
We didn’t prep any of this. He’s just shooting from the hip. Dixon gets the attention of a young female staffer, GINNY TERZANO. He motions for a coffee. She nods and walks off.
She’s not the one who gets the coffee.
We'll need water for the press. Maybe oxygen.
And beer.

That he was born?

That’s not the problem. Gary looks up from the application.

One bed or two? A beat. There is more to this conversation. Andrea hasn’‘ come out of the closet, but there is an understanding. GARY (CONT’D) Hotel rooms aren’t cheap... (smiles) Make an economics argument. She smiles and nods a thank you.

Quieter now as Hart moves briskly from cubicle to cubicle accompanied by Dixon and Shore, meeting the STAFF. (over the wind) Yeah, remind me when we —  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 28.

Exactly. The west is the future. It always has been. And it still is. OFF Hart, hair whipping in the wind, moving back to his podium spot. Belongs to a guy named Soffer. Real nice guy. Owns a shit ton of real estate down here. EXT. ABOARD THE MONKEY BUSINESS. NIGHT. A PARTY AT SEA! A senator?

Wow. Like, in Florida?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 30. Broadhurst leans into Hart. He points at a couple rich gu across the way, asking if Hart wants to meet them.

Not interested. An attractive 29 year old blonde joins the group. She whispers something in Armandt’s ear. This is DONNA RICE. Rice introduces herself but Hart can barely hear her name EXT. THE MONKEY BUSINESS. DAY. The yacht drifts on the open ocean. Music now twinkling i the distance.

I intend -- as I always have -- to run a campaign of ideas. EXT. RED ROCKS STATE PARK, COLORADO. DAY. For a moment, we see a caravan of reporters hiking up to press conference as they struggle to breath.

Ideas have power. Ideas are what governing is all about. TIME CUT - A CAMERAMAN is on his knees in the orange dust massively heavy camera slung on his shoulder. We see Parker taking notes. Fielder a couple rows back. H stands without podium, framed by the majestic rocks. HART (CONT’D) We are running for the highest and most important office in the land. We find Emerson, Shore and Stratton in a heated discussio
It is your job, specifically, to convince the senator not to do things exactly like this.
What exactly do you want me to say?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 31.
That he’s going to look like an idiot... or worse, kill somebody. What the fuck is an axe throwing contest anyway?
I believe they call it Timbersport.
I can look into light weight axes.
Like, for children?
Roosevelt was an outdoorsman. He killed a grizzly once. (aside) You know that’s where teddy bears came from?
Fuck off.
He’s correct.
It’s true. Teddy Roosevelt killed a giant bear and they commemorated it by making plush toys for children. It was a national sensation.
Maybe he'd settle for log rolling?
How will they commemorate Gary Hart impaling a lumberjack?

Might play well with the far left. INT. HART CAMPAIGN PLANE. 90 MINUTES LATER. No one obeys the traditional rules of flying. People mill around seats and stand in the aisle and perform interview Meanwhile, Hart, chin in hand, alone, staring out the win Nearby, Ann McDaniel is working Sweeney for time with Har  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 32.
Sure looks overjoyed to be going home after thirty years.
(swigging beer) The Senator has very fond memories of Kansas. He cannot wait.

No one has fond memories of Kansas. We find Dixon, Germond, Broder and Wyman playing cards. W watching them from behind the economy curtain. In the BAC with most of the REPORTERS. Parker watches carefully. An ORANGE enters foreground. A Sharpie scrawls a message the peel. After a big windup, Weinberg rolls the orange u the aisle of the plane. It disappears into the front cabi A few REPORTERS cheer in their seats. We notice TOM FIEDL early 30s and nerdy, among them. He feels on the outside.
What’d you write on it?
I asked where the goddamn food is.
Good. I’m starving. What do they have in Kansas? Hardys?
Arbys. Parker looks up to first class. He sees Germond, Broder a Wyman leaving the front section and heading back. Billy picks up the ORANGE. Shows it to Hart. He smiles.
Remember this time last year? Our bus had a flat outside Dubuque. Parker is watching Hart chuckle in response, when Sweeney arrives at his seat.
We've got a few minutes now if you're ready. Parker practically hops out of his seat.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 33.
Go get’em tiger. FIEDLER NOTICES and pulls Sweeney into the galley.
Hey, when can I get some face time with the Senator?
We'll do a presser in Kansas.
I mean one on one.
We’re not doing that this time.
(motions to Parker) What do you call that?

The Washington Post. Sweeney keeps moving as Fiedler takes this in. Just then Weinberg notices the orange a few feet away, tumbling back down the aisle. He reaches out and grabs it We see the words written on the orange in all caps: “HAVE ORANGE. - GARY.” INT. HART CAMPAIGN PLANE. FIVE MINUTES LATER. Off the flipping of a NOTEPAD, we find Hart and Parker fa each other in the front, with Sweeney watching carefully.
But you think the president hasn't gone far enough?
I know he hasn’t. I know Gorbachev too, don’t forget.
What can we do? Aside from negotiate more reductions.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 34.
There won't be any peace dividend if we don’t meet Gorbachev more than halfway. I'd invite him to my inauguration.
(doubtful) The Soviet premier.
Sure. Why wouldn’t he come? Why wouldn't we show him democracy in action? We need to be bolder.
You really think that might lay the groundwork for more negotiations?
Groundwork? The groundwork is laid. A BUMP OF TURBULENCE rocks the cabin for a moment. Gary casually catches his drink. Parker grabs his armrests.
(calming) It’s just wind.
Yeah, uh huh. A few more bumps. Parker doesn’t love it.
Close your eyes. (off Parker’s reluctance) Seriously. Parker finally shuts his eyes.
We're driving down a country road. The cabin jostles again.
See. We hit a few bumps. Truck keeps going. You’ve been doing this your whole life. Some roads aren't paved. That’s all. The plane settles. Parker opens his eyes.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 35.
(embarrassed) Thank you.
You got it... So the Soviets are in an economic tailspin, but change has to be managed. Otherwise you'll get a power vacuum, in Asia and the MidEast. You know what fills vacuums?
Human nature?
Exactly. Wars. Dictators. Religious extremism.
That's your view of human nature?
Didn't they teach you Tolstoy at..?
Yale. I was a history major.
(rummaging for a book) Here. (hands him a worn copy of Resurrection) It’'ll teach you something about the Soviets, too.
Thank you. I’1ll get it back to you.
Keep it. I’m not a library.

Staffers and journalists exit the plane and try to make s of their next move as they wander towards the terminal. EXT. MAIN STREET, OTTAWA, KANSAS. DAY. The Hart MOTORCADE enters the town square. People take notice. Some wave.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 36. Inside, Hart looks out with mixed feelings for his childh
Hart has a private moment in the church he grew up in. It quiet and kind of beautiful. An organ player sits down an warms up the keys.
Hart is midway through an ordinary policy speech for a la group of locals who are listening, but not very engaged.
As we move toward the end of this long, dark chapter in our history, new challenges lie ahead... Dixon, Wilson, and Shore speak quietly in the wings.
We flew to Ottawa fucking Kansas to give a policy speech? He’s supposed to be getting personal.
Personal is not a comfort zone.
If it’s any consolation, He is hitting all of the four E’s.
We added an E? EXT. HART CHILDHOOD HOME, OTTAWA. DAY. Hart and Lee, surrounded by a PACK OF REPORTERS, stand in front of a rickety clapboard house. ROADWORK is being done across the street.
How does it feel to be back home?
We...uh... We actually lived in six different houses. My dad, he was out of work a lot. The campaign team just hangs back. Quietly stewing.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 37.
(quietly) I know, I know. Christ, just say it’s good to be home. Hart kind of notices his guys grumbling. Lee brightens.
(prompting) Remember George used to sit out here all day?

Of course... Whenever I got home, my granddad would always be sitting here on the front porch with a Bible open in his lap. Every day. One time a neighbor asks him, just to be friendly, “What are you doing up there?” Grandad says, “Cramming for finals.” Lee and the reporters laugh. More photos. Hart turns and gives a reluctant smile.
AN ELDER WOMAN VOLUNTEER drives the team. They seem to ha lost their way and the staff is AUDIBLY UPSET.
(prickishly clarifying) You've been to the airport before.
Yes, just never in a van.
(quietly) Where did we find her?
Are we going to swing through the South or not?
Why waste the money?
(to the volunteer) How would you get there in a car?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 38.
(found a map) We can turn right on the farm road.
State directors in Georgia and Alabama are begging.
That was the farm road.
Carter won the South.
Carter was the South. Trust me, it’s already gone.
Irene’s right. I’m not writing off the South.
I can give you the numbers.
I intend to be the president of the entire country. Not 35 states. If my ideas make sense in Youngstown, they’1l make sense in Mobile.
(dryly) And we get to go to Alabama.
(re: volunteer driver) Dear God, she ran a green.
They've arrived at the AIRPORT. Everyone exits in a hurry Hart puts his hand on the ELDERLY VOLUNTEER’s shoulder. H gives her a smile and she immediately relaxes.

STAFF and REPORTERS buzz around the terminal. WEINBERG, SHANAHAN, and a STRINGER read off stories into PAYPHONES. Hart sits between Sweeney and Shore, tinkering with a fir generation, shoe-size cellphone.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 39. Stratton approaches the press corps in the background.
It’s a 30-minute delay, guys. Go get a sandwich. Stratton walks back towards Wilson and Emerson.
It’s a travesty.
A designer suit?
It’s not about the suit. It’s the presentation of things.
What’s this?
Ralph Lauren announced they’re doing wardrobe for CBS News.
You prefer Hugo Boss?
There’s that word - Wardrobe. Like they’re on Three's Company
It is a television show.
No, it’s the news... A bad suit should mean something. It’s trustworthy. We see Hart hits a key on the phone and holds it up.
Why isn’t it ringing?
Did you hit send? Do you see any bars?
(holding out his hand) You have to hit send. I’1l do it.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 40.
(rising) Keep it. I’1l be back. Back to Emerson... Getting more heated.
It starts with designer clothes. And everyone says - Don’t they look nice - Pretty soon Vidal Sassoon is doing Tom Brokow’s hair.
(poking the bear) Maybe some music.
Sure, Mark Knopfler’s writing some opening theme song and they‘1l have action shots of the anchors leaping away from fires and pulling kittens out of storm drains.
Hey, maybe they don’t even need to read the news...
Fuck, why have newsmen at all...? Let’s just hire models and teach them to read. You know, someone you can really jerk off to.
(genuinely amused) That’s funny.
It’s not Doug. It’s not funny at all. It’s the Death Nail of journalism.
Do you mean Death Knell? It’s a common mistake.

How often do people just punch you in the face? We find Parker grabbing a coke from a vending machine. Something catches his eye. He stares a moment, curiously.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 41. CUT TO Sweeney, still in his seat, clocking the same thin Parker's looking at: Hart crammed into a phone booth, hea down, talking quietly with a big grin. Parker and Sweeney make eye contact, and then a GATE ANNOUNCEMENT draws their curiosity away.

THWACK! An ax lands solidly in a wooden BULLSEYE. EXT. NORTH COUNTRY, NEW HAMPSHIRE. DAY. Two strong hands yank the ax out of the log. A burly LUMBERJACK hands the LARGE AXE to Hart, who wears flannel shirt and jeans. The crowd whispers in anticipation. Quick shot of a gaggle of reporters, Parker among them, snickering skeptically. Fiedler, from the Miami Herald, l a TWENTY DOLLAR BILL towards Parker.
Ten bucks says he misses.
I’m alright, thanks. Fiedler shrugs. Suit yourself. Quick POP of Sweeney, head in hands.

This is a first... He might just actually throw away his campaign. I can’t fucking watch this. Shore, munching on an apple, looks on with detachment. Hart, smiling, lifts the ax over his head and hurls with his might. It travels 25 feet and - THWACK! A dead bulls- Even the reporters CHEER as Hart lifts his arms above his head and grins triumphantly. Parker gives Fiedler a little nod. Shore looks at Emerson

(euphoric) That was incredible.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 42. Gary starts working his way through a line of WOODSMEN, e to shake his hand, particularly after that throw. However there’s a few dissenters including one particularly ANGRY WOODSMAN who keeps his hands in his pockets.
(passive aggressive) Just keep your hand out of my pocket.
What was that?
Taxes are high enough. Keep your hand out of my pocket. The woodsman begins to walk away. Hart kind of smiles...
So, are we going to talk or are you just going to walk away? The woodsman turns back. Caught off guard and a little sheepish. Hart is unflinching.
What’s a good place to get a beer around here?

Rifles on racks. Timbersport pros and hunters have formed horseshoe around Hart in the smoky hall. It’s quiet. No o knows where to start. Hart sees the angry woodsman from earlier. He rolls back sleeves, shows his hands, and smiles.
Your pockets are safe. Chuckles around the room.
So, where should we start? Note: in this scene, questions will come from the crowd. won’t see each person talk. The group is speaking as a wh  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 43.
What are we supposed to ask?
Let’s talk about anything you want. We find the campaign team on the side visibly nervous.
Where’s the beef?! Chuckles around.
(smiles) Haven't heard that one in a while.
You a Christian?
Yes I am.
You think they should have prayer in school?
I like prayer in church.
Do you hunt?
Not so much. When I was a kid, my uncle taught me to track bears.
You going to take our guns?
You going to take mine? This calms the room a bit for a beat.
What about Mexicans?
What about them?
They're taking our jobs.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 44,
(thinks for a moment) You think they want to leave their lives behind? Their families? (stops) Would you?
They’11l work for nothing.
That's why we need to invest in Mexico.
You want to buy a jalapeno farm?
Is that what you do? You’re a farmer?
I make chairs.
(riffing) So why don’t we invest in their enterprise? Their industry. Create opportunity for Mexicans in Mexico. Instead of stealing your jobs, they’1l buy your chairs.
They're not very good chairs.
Well, I can’t help him with that. (a thought) I mean, forget jobs for a second, think about security. You really want a chaotic nation on the brink of economic collapse just south of the border?
Sounds like Massachusetts. Real laughter.
So you anti-military or something?
Why do you say that?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 45.
You're a democrat.
(incredulous) I’m in the military.
What branch?
Navy reserve. A couple chuckles.
Does that not count?
You want to cut the military?
I want to reform it.
That means cut it.

I disagree. I actually wrote an entire book on military reform. Sold twelve copies. I don’t suppose anyone here read it? (looks to his staff) Any of you guys? Sheepish looks amongst his team. Wilson raises his hand.
(quietly) It’s a good read.
You say you’re worried about your taxes. You know how much that new B2 Bomber costs? About a billion dollars.
Worth every penny.
Is it? Sure, they might look pretty flying over the Superbowl. (MORE )
Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 46.
But let’s face it, we're building a military that’s only good at bombing. And after twenty years of bombing, you know what we’ll be left with? He looks around the room, genuinely open for an answer.
Rubble. Rubble that we’ll need to rebuild. And people who hate us. But we won’t have a conventional military ready to fight in the jungles and deserts where they hate us the most.
Nuke ‘em.

Okay. Sure. Who you going to nuke? (long beat) The cold war is over and our addiction to oil is going to take us into battles we don’t know how to fight in places like the middle east, where stateless Islamic terrorism will become an epidemic.
I’m not worried about some ragheads in the desert...
You should be. Their bombs won’t have a return address.
Celtics or Lakers?

Nuggets. Boos rain down from all the men. HART (CONT’D) (laughing) I’m not afraid of being booed. More laughter. There’s an awkward pause. Feels like they’ running out of questions.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 47.
If you get elected, are you ever going to come back to this town.
A long beat.

What do you mean “if”? He smiles. The men laugh. The room has been defused. INT. BAR AT THE WAYFARER INN, MANCHESTER, NH. NIGHT. Hart gets up from a table of the old guard reporters. The laughing about the day’s events. The CAMPAIGN TEAM is at a table, talking about the next s Hart heads for the bathroom when he stops at the KIDS TAB
What’s the news, guys?
Cuomo is officially out. The young reporters watch Hart’s face waiting for a react Hart has a small smile, then catches himself.
Long way to go.
Kennedy, Bradley... All out.
I like Gephardt. Al’s still in this thing. Jesse Jackson.
Come on... I mean, Senator, sir.
He’s got double digits.
You think this country will elect Jesse Jackson president?
Maybe vice president.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 48.
That’s what Jesse really wants anyway, right? Hart smiles just as a waitress arrives.
They need another round. On me.
You can’t do that. It’s...
Fine, another round on them.
Word is you're going to be president.
I don’t know, how does secretary of the navy sound?

Already been a secretary, honey. But you’re sweet. INT. WAYFARER INN. MOMENTS LATER. Hart follows a sign to the RESTROOM. He’s smiling about t Cuomo news. He turns the corner and stops, flustered. Weinberg and a woman reporter from the pool are leaned up against a wall, giggling and making out. Both wear WEDDIN RINGS they did not exchange with each other. Hart kind of smiles and quietly enters the mens room. INT. MIAMI HERALD CONFERENCE ROOM. MORNING. About a dozen editors and reporters sit and stand around long conference table, among them FIEDLER from the pool. BOB MARTINDALE, the paper’s editor, sits at the head of t table. Another editor, JOE SAVAGE, sits nearby. An investigative reporter named MURPHY is dramatically recounting the movements of a drug cartel.
They fly in below the radar, cruising a hundred feet above the water like Apaches on a strafe run. (MORE )
Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 49.

Right before they breach our airspace, they dump the whole fucking shipment into the Atlantic - not pounds... tons of coke. A Volkswagon of coke - where they’ve got cigarette boats that kick the shit out of our coast guard.
You saw this?
Got an old Navy buddy. Runs fishing tours out of Islamorada. Spent five nights under a cargo net.
Nice. Let’s work up some sort of map that shows the route and make sure we’ve got artwork on those cigarette boats in motion. Not some bullshit stock photo, but really kicking up surf.
(dry) Got it. Sexy boats kicking up surf.
Anything from the Mickey Desk?
MGM is suing Disney World over the new park. It’s a license violation.
No shit. Could it scuttle the deal?
Tim’s trying to nail it down.
Let’s get a top for front page. Maybe some options on a crying Mickey drawing.
We've done crying Mickey. Twice. When Universal came to Orlando and when that alligator ate that kid near Epcot.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 50.
Right. Try Mickey in hand cuffs. Politics?
Yeah, just got back from the kickoff tour with Gary Hart.
(to Fiedler) Okay. Anything new there?
I mean, it’s the curtain raiser on the guy who’s going to win the presidency. The ASSISTANT EDITOR, a woman in her late 40s, speaks up
Keep it to 100 twills, Tom. We’re tight today.
Are you serious?

(moving on) Sports. Who the Dolphins drafting? INT. MIAMI HERALD NEWSROOM. MONDAY NIGHT, APRIL 27. Fiedler, reading through clips, has his feet up on his de in the mostly deserted newsroom. Baseball on the transistor radio. The desk phone rings. H picks up. We don’t see the face of the coy, yet tipsy, Da Weems on the other side of the call.
Tom Fiedler - - - Hello?
Did you write the story about Gary Hart today?
(half-listening) Yeah, that was me.
Um... He’s having an affair with a friend of mine.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 51.
What?
We’re on a street corner. The phone booth is fogged. Insi is DANA WEEMS, a friend of Donna Rice from the boat. Outs bolstering her friend, is Lynn Armandt.
She's sneaking around with him.
(doesn’t buy it) Okay, right and how do you know?
(giggling) I mean, it’s all she talks about.
What’s her name? What’s your name?
(giggling again) I can’t tell you that!
Look, this isn’t funny, OK? You can’t just call people and make allegations. Now, who are you and --
She's flying up there. To see him in Washington. This weekend.
This weekend?
Friday, yeah. Maybe you can follow her or something. God, she’s so pathetic. Like a cheerleader getting notes from the popular boy, you know? Fiedler finds a crinkly faxed sheet.
(eyeing the sheet) Hart’s not in DC this weekend. (MORE )
Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 52.
He’s going to Kentucky for the derby. Sorry lady...
Wait. It’s just, I want to ask you.
Uh huh?
Do you guys pay for pictures?
Jesus... Good luck. He hangs up on her. Shakes his head.
A CAMPAIGN AD is being edited on an old tape-to-tape onli bay. Dixon and Sweeney watch and criticize ad lib. COMMERCIAL: Gary Hart amongst nature. Speaking to camera.

... Now over the next year, you’re going to see a lot of campaign ads. Many of which will have some kind of faceless announcer. But not from me. I believe a candidate should stand by what they believe in rather than hide behind some stranger's voice. So, next time you hear that faceless announcer making claims and accusations, ask yourself why. As the HART ‘88 LOGO comes up we find Stratton and Wilson They're admiring all the HOLLYWOOD PHOTOS at Emerson's de In them, Emerson hangs out with 1980’s icons like Nichols Beatty, Hunter S. Thompson, Don Johnson.
Must be hard to be away from all your friends back home.
Yeah, okay, I ran the California office. These were my constituents.
Warren Beatty and Jack Nicholson?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 53.
«+. Yes. They’re both Angelinos.
On those particularly tough nights, it must be reassuring to look over and see their faces.
Do they serve as a reminder of the regional struggles in California?
Warren Beatty is a thoughtful... political... Fuck both of you. We find Hart in the front corner, feet up on Sweeney’s de gazing out the window, talking on a corded phone.

Well thank you. I mean it, Ed. (listens but glances away) Well we will, and Lee and I appreciate it. Hal will call you about where to send the check and all that... Righto. Talk soon. He hangs up and we PAN to see Kelly and Shore.
You're a free man.
Thank you. Until call time tomorrow. Hart walks by staffers pulling out new HART SIGNS.
Oh Irene, tell Steve and Kitty I can’t make Kentucky, OK?
You're gonna miss the derby?
And tell Ellie to grab coffee? INT. MIAMI HERALD NEWSROOM. DAY. FRIDAY, MAY 1. A TELETYPE MACHINE printing out the following:
Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 54. We find Fiedler eating a sandwich.
(to another reporter) You never get the tacos. Someone should have told you that.
But Friday's taco day, man.
Let me know how Saturday goes. The mail clerk, an old guy with a limp, wheels his mail c past the desk and stops.
Thanks Earl. He stares at the sheet. Fiedler’s brain clicks. He starts walking. We follow Fiedler to Murphy’s desk.
Hey, what’s doing?
I think I need your help on something.
Stratton is attempting to demonstrate the best way to coo HAMBURGER. He’s using a RULER as a spatula and a flattene ball of lined paper as a BURGER.
I know how to make a burger, Mike.
If they see you flip it twice... Others from the team chime in.
(dicking around) What else will he flip on... healthcare... farming subsidies...?
I’m serious.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 55.

Hart in an apron, poses with the RESTAURANT STAFF for a f photos. He flips burgers. Parker watches from nearby. Moments later, Hart is at a table facing Parker. A tape recorder sits between them on the table.
(to Parker) We almost done?
Just about.
You read the book yet?
Just about. It’s Tolstoy. Parker looks down at his notepad. A series of questions h been crossed off. One word remains - “Marriage”.
(visibly uncomfortable) Can we talk about your separation. Sweeney looks up.
It’s a fairly common occurrence. I'd avoid it if you can.
I’m not having fun asking about this. In case you were wondering.
I wasn’t.
AJ... Look --
Why should anyone care? How is it relevant?
People feel like it’s hard to Senator... know you. I’m trying to help elucidate --  Some of us Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 56.
People. Who are these ‘people’ everyone keeps telling me about?
Fine, maybe we feel that way.
So, reporters.
. AJ, either ask something else... HART (CONT’D) Some of you who were in high school when I ran McGovern’s campaign. It’s not my fault you’re just arriving at the party.
OK, so around that time, you told Gail Sheehy you believed in “reform marriage.” What did that mean?

For crying out loud. I was young and tired and living across the country from my wife, and I made a stupid joke. You know, this is why people don’t want to be in public life. Because someone will dredge up something you said in a moment 15 years ago and act like it somehow encapsulates your life.
It’s just --
I’m going to answer one more of these, and then I’m not going to sit here anymore. We’ve covered all the stuff that matters. Did anyone ask Reagan about his marriage?
I don’t think -- Let’s wrap this up...
Did you ask Carter these questions?
There’ve been rumors --  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 57.
Oh for God sake, AJ. Ask whatever it is you came here to ask.
OK. Do you think you have... A traditional marriage?
(disbelief) OK. That’s enough. We’re done A trad -- here--

You want to know what I’m doing in my spare time? Is that it, AJ? Follow me around then. Put a tail on me. I mean it. You'd be very bored. Parker scribbles, head down as Sweeney escorts Hart away. INT. MIAMI INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT. FRIDAY AFTERNOON. We're watching the ESCALATORS, over the shoulders of Fied and Murphy. Mostly tourists and businessmen. Fiedler is flipping through a magazine nervously. He’s so nervous, i comical. Murphy is trying to keep it cool.
Just calm down.
What am I supposed to do?
Act bored. Most people usually look bored. What does she look like?
Attractive. Hot enough to make you leave your wife.

Honestly wouldn’t take much. Murphy looks ready to give up and then they see her. DONN Armandt walks alongside her. Without saying a word, they begin following her towards the gate.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 58.

Fiedler and Murphy sit deep in coach. Fiedler leans into aisle to get a look at Donna who’s reading a book a few r down. He leans a little further and is suddenly hit by th BEVERAGE CART, making a bit of a mess. He flinches back.
Fiedler and Murphy walk 15 feet behind Donna and Armandt, trying to play it cool.
Donna and Armandt are shown into a waiting cab. Several people back in the line, Fiedler and Murphy watch anxiously as their marks pull away.
Do we know where they’re going?

I fucking hope so. EXT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE, CAPITOL HILL. FRIDAY NIGHT. Fiedler’s TAXI comes up on a stately, two-story row house Lights shine in the windows and illuminate the sidewalk. No one’s visible inside or out. Fiedler and Murphy fight for the driver’s side window.
This one here on the left.
You want me to pull over?
Just hang a second.
No security? Nothing? You sure this is right?
It’s his place.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 59.
(looking at the house) You guys getting out? Doesn't feel right.
Just give us a second. Fiedler looks at the windows, hoping for an answer.
No secret service?
He isn’t the nominee yet.
Look, I’m not sure what you guys are up to...
(to Fiedler) I think you got taken buddy.
We've been here all of two fucking seconds...
This isn’t a peep show, one of you has to pay me...!
New destination, we need a hotel...
Hold on! Suddenly, the lights turn off inside the house. Fiedler and Murphy go silent.
Which one of you is going to...?

(quietly) Pull over there. The cab pulls over. Inside, they all hold still, waiting see what will happen next. We SEE the front door open. A man’s arm holds it open. Hart and Donna come out onto the stoop.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 60.
Fuck me. Broadhurst and Armandt follow. They walk down to Hart’s SEDAN, all get in and drive off. BACK TO Fiedler, suddenly vibrating with mixed energy.
We’re gonna need a photographer.

head_text.subj: THE BACK OF AN SLR CAMERA BEING LOADED WITH FILM

text: EXT. STREET OUTSIDE HART’S TOWNHOUSE, CAPITOL HILL. DAWN. Murphy sit in a rental car outside the house, as the sun appears on the horizon. He does a crossword. In the back with the camera is ROY VALENTINE, a photographer.
You're sure they’re in there?
Yep. Have you staked out before?
(scoffs) I mean, I’m not a paparazzi. Are we even allowed to do this?

A few years ago, I figured out most of the planes carrying kilos of coke into the US weren’t coming from Colombia. They're actually coming from the fucking Bahamas. So I dig a little deeper. Turns out, the prime minister is taking pay offs from Miami lawyers to leave beach front runways unguarded.
Wo.
Yeah, “Wo”. Sometimes you need to catch someone in the act. I mean, fuck, have you ever had to do this kind of investigative journalism?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 61.

(uncomfortable sharing) Last year, I snuck into the Magic Kingdom as a tourist. I cut right into Tomorrowland, bought a rocket pop, and when no one was looking, I climbed a barricade and caught the first images of Captain EO. (long beat) It was terrifying, but worth it. A long look from Murphy. Suddenly, THE DOOR OPENS. It’s Fiedler. He’s holding a printed out FAX.
Follow me around. (passes it to Murphy) Hart told the Post to follow him around...
“Follow me around. Put a tail on me. You’d be very bored.”
He asked _ us to follow him.
Technically speaking, we were already following him.
Are you fucking kidding me?

It’s an invitation. (off Roy’s skepticism) Look, if this were 20 years ago and party bosses were still picking the candidates in back rooms, that would be one thing. But things changed. Everyone forgets that. They just handed these primaries and caucuses back to some folks in Iowa lined up around the Country Kitchen to pick nominees they've never heard of, you know, to vet some governor or congressman from god knows where? We have a responsibility here... to hold these guys accountable.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 62. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE HART’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY It’s RAINING. The rental car sits there. Three silhouette behind the windshield. Inside, they’re eating individual cartons of Chinese. Jus watching and waiting for something to happen. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE HART’S TOWNHOUSE - AFTERNOON The car parked in the same spot. Murphy and Roy asleep. Fiedler looks up from his newspaper. He SEES a WOMAN WITH A BABY CARRIAGE, and then a JOGGER. Then, WILSON (policy aide) approaching the front door. Murphy sits up for a better look. He lowers the window an inch, hoping to hear. We barely hear the DOORBELL. A moment later, the townhouse door opens revealing Hart, wearing a white hoodie and jeans. Wilson hands Hart a thick envelope. We barely make out wh they’re saying.
Thanks.
Hopefully this is the last draft.

Yeah, I’1l give it a look... And then Hart freezes. He seems to be either lost in thou or STARING STRAIGHT AT THE RENTAL CAR. Fiedler holds stoc still, not sure whether to go back to his paper or drive when Hart gives a quick goodbye to Wilson and shuts the d Fiedler gives Murphy a shove.
What’s happening?
Wilson, policy guy.
What is that, a speech writer?
To a certain... He studies the fluctuations in foreign... and... (MORE )
Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 63.
(Murphy doesn’t care) Yes, he’s a speech writer.
Did he make you?
Don’t think so. Need a closer look. Thinks for a second.

head_text.subj: TAGS BEING RIPPED OFF NEW JOGGING CLOTHES

text: EXT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE - LATE IN THE DAY Fiedler, pretending to run in a ridiculous jogging suit, trots past the rental car, giving Murphy a furtive glance He jogs onto the sidewalk and slows down as he passes Har townhouse. He’s trying to see through the windows but can quite make anything out. INT./EXT. FIEDLER’S RENTAL CAR - LAST LIGHT Fiedler finishes his loop and jogs back up to the rental and gets back in the passenger seat. He’s sweating... Har
Jesus, you ran around the block.
Fuck off. (looking for Roy) Where’s our shooter? Murphy nods toward the house. We SEE Roy with his CAMERA, crouching behind a bush, trying to get a good angle.
Are you fucking kidding me?
He’s young, excited. What was I going to say?
He’s going to get us caught. We watch from the car as Roy gets closer to the townhouse Suddenly one by one, the WINDOW BLINDS SLAM SHUT.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 64.

Fuck. EXT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE - NIGHT A beat as they watch the townhouse. The last glow of ambi daylight disappears into night. And then the front door of the townhouse opens. Hart come down the steps, still wearing his white hoodie. Hart climbs inside his Chrysler. He’s visibly nervous. A stark difference from his usual confidence and calm. Hart checks the mirror as he pulls out slowly onto the street. We SEE the Herald’s rental car reflected in the mirror, pulling out to follow him. Hart puts on his blinker and deliberately takes a right t onto a side street. He checks the mirror again, sees the following. His jaw clenches. His breathing grows shallow. We can alm hear his adrenaline. He pulls to a slow crawl at a stop sign, waiting for the Herald car to get close enough, and then Hart hits the br - His TAIL LIGHTS illuminate the car behind him. We can’t quite make out details, but we see three male fa bathed in a red glow. He shakes his head to himself. Hart hits the gas. Quickly, he makes three right turns, bringing us back to... EXT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE, CAPITOL HILL - NIGHT Hart re-parks the car outside his house. He takes a deep breath. He gets out and looks behind him at the Herald’s rental car, which has come to a stop a few car-lengths aw He puts his head down, shoves his hands into his pockets, heads off briskly into the side alley. The moment he rounds the corner, the Herald team quickly pulls over and jumps out of the car. They briskly follow the mouth of the alley, visually checking in with each ot as they walk.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 65. EXT. SIDE ALLEY BY HART’S TOWNHOUSE - NIGHT The three Herald guys, Murphy leading the way, head towar intersection where a side alley meets a BACK ALLEY.
(hissing) You were too close.
(hissing back) He was already on to us. As they turn the corner into the back alley --

Good evening, gentlemen. Standing in front of them, in his white hoodie, is HART. A long silent beat. The three journalists from the Herald line up across from Hart. Murphy out front. Fiedler in th shadows. There’s an eerie High Noon quality to the stand No one knows what to do. No one has ever been here before For better or for worse, they've breached a historical tr between candidate and the press... and they must figure o the next moment on their own.
(nervous ) Good evening, Senator. I'ma reporter for the Miami Herald. We'd like to talk to you. Hart holds his ground, trying to decipher what’s happenin
Um... We’d like to ask you about the woman who’s been staying in your townhouse. Hart doesn’t move. Composes his thoughts specifically.
.-+. No one is staying in my townhouse.
We saw you leave and return with a woman last night. A blond woman?
I may. I may not have.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 66.
We saw you.
I don’t know what you think you saw... FLASH - Roy takes a photo. It’s blinding and confusing in dark alleyway. It almost feels like a gun shot. Fiedler steps forward.
Hello, Senator.
(registering Fiedler) Tom?
Yes, sir. I uhh... I wonder if you could tell us whether this woman works for the campaign. (beat) The one we saw you with.
She is not part of my campaign.
Okay. Then can you tell us how you know her? FLASH - Another photo startles Hart.
Well... I don’t think that’s relevant.
(scoffing) Oh, I assure you, Senator, it’s relevant --
It’s just that, we saw you leave and come back with this woman. And we didn’t see her leave again.
Tom, you can’t be serious. No one is staying in my home but me.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 67.
I am serious, sir. How long have you known her?
What kind of questions are these?
Is she a friend?
I don’t know why I would tell you that. Tom, I am not --
Can you produce the woman so she can corroborate what you’re saying?

I don’t have to produce... This has gone on long enough. Hart takes a step forward, as if to leave, and Roy snaps more photos, blinding Hart momentarily. Hart blinks. The flashes begin to build now, more and more - Frustrating H
Senator, we know you’ve made calls to this woman. You called her from Kansas. And New Hampshire. We have the dates.
I make calls every day. I don’t see how I’d remember, and I don’t see how you’d -- FLASH, FLASH...
(stammering) But... Senator... I was at your announcement speech. You said... you said... We must...
(from his notebook) .+. I know what I said. “Hold ourselves to the highest possible standards of integrity and ethics.”  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 68.
So why am I standing here? Why am I standing here in an alley ona Saturday night? Don’t you think you owe it to us to be forthcoming? FLASH, FLASH...
(scoffs) Owe you?
You're denying what we've seen with our own eyes!
The only thing I deny is the idea that somehow you have the right to ask these things.
You're running for president!
I’m aware of that, Tom. It’s in the papers. FLASH, FLASH...
Then you have a responsibility --
I know full well what my responsibilities are. (taking a step forward) Do you know yours? Hart goes to leave, but Murphy steps into his path.
Senator. Have you had sex with this woman? !
What?! FLASH, FLASH...
You should be ashamed of yourself. (to Fiedler) (MORE )

Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 69. HART (CONT’D) The only one putting you in this alley, Tom, is you. Hart moves to the back door of the townhouse amidst multi FLASHES... And then he’s gone. A moment as the two journalists and the photographer catc their breath and look at each other - What just happened? And then they scuttle off down the alleyway. We boom up t WINDOW and find Hart catching his breath. He grabs for a phone. Begins to dial.
(through the window) Yeah, Billy. Find Dixon. Now.

location: QUALITY INN GUEST ROOM, CAPITOL HILL

text: Fiedler, Murphy, and Roy rush into the room. Fiedler open his giant TANDY LAPTOP. INT. BROADHURST’S KITCHEN, CAPITOL HILL. 9 PM SATURDAY.
Think. Donna and Armandt sit on the velour couch in front of him
Maybe you told somebody. Your momma. Your mailman. Somebody.
We didn’t.
I’m asking Donna.
Oh my God. You think... He's going to think I told someone.
Donna, darling, I need you to be straight with me here.
I told you, I didn’t -- Don’t reporters follow him all the time?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 70.
Gary says these guys are from Miami. Which means they're following you, not Gary, OK?

I don’t know any reporters, Billy. I don’t know anyone. INT. QUALITY INN GUEST ROOM, CAPITOL HILL. 10 PM. Smoke in the air, coffee cups, detritus everywhere. Fiedl frantically bangs out copy while Murphy hovers behind. We GLIMPSE Roy, the photographer, in the bathroom develop his NEGATIVES with a mini-daylight tank over the sink, ha listening. One roll is already hanging and drying.
(checking his watch) 42 minutes. (eyeing the screen) You want to say linked here. Saying she’s tied to Hart makes it sound -
Professional?
No, like ropes and chains and shit. Fiedler grunts, nods and keeps typing. The phone rings.
(to Roy) Can you grab that?
(adding chemicals to the developing tank) A little busy here.
(answering) Hey... Uh huh... (mutes the phone) They want to hold for a day, just to get our shit straight. Maybe get the girl’s name.
Can’t. We lose half the readers.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 71.
(back on the phone) This can’t wait til Monday. It’s a Sunday story. (muting the phone) They want to know if we saw the girl with our own eyes.
(still typing furiously) We did.
I mean we saw her... arrive.
Interview or conversation?
Interview? In an alleyway?
Watergate started with an interview in a parking garage. A moment. That word. Watergate. INT. BROADHURST’S KITCHEN, CAPITOL HILL. CONTINUOUS. TIGHT ON the RINGING phone.
(answering, harried) Hello. (beat) Ok. Hang on. (to Donna) It’s for you.
(taking the corded phone) Hello? INTERCUT as needed with -- Hart in GEORGETOWN.
Hello.
Gary! Thank God. What’s happening?
I don’t know. I thought you might.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 72.
What? Behind her, the sound of shattering glass.
Goddamnit.
(looking behind her) No. I... look, I need you to know, I had nothing to do with this. I’ve never talked to those men. I don’t know any reporters.
Get me that broom, would you sweetheart?
They knew I’d called you. They knew where I was.
I don’t understand.
(Kneeling over glass) Ow! Goddamn!
What’s going on over there?
BB dropped a glass, I guess. He’s upset. We’re all upset.
It’ll be fine. Trust me.
Do you trust me?
I want to trust you. (a tough beat) I may not be seeing you again.
What?
Good night, Miss Rice.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 73. Off Donna as his icy words take the breath from her lungs

Martindale exits the elevator and looks up to see Joe Sav already in the lit conference room. They both clearly got pulled out of bed and returned to work. A beat later, we find them huddled over the conference ph
It’s not our quote.
(speakerphone) We need the quote.
You want the quote.

location: QUALITY INN GUEST ROOM, CAPITOL HILL

text: Murphy is still holding the phone to his ear.
(quietly) We could credit the Post?
Yeah, yeah... Hart told The Post to “follow him around”...?
Is there a chance the senator was being facetious? Murphy shoots Roy a look.
So now we’re advertising for the Post?
We could run an 800 number for new subscribers.
Fuck you, Jim.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 74.
(laughs ) We could just tease the interview. Follow up later in the week.
(shaking his head) They're going to find a way to spin this thing. We’ve got him right now. Dead to rights.
Easy there Magnum, this isn’t a drug bust.
He was asking for it. That’s a story. That is the story.
(already typing) “In an interview with the Post, he challenged those who questioned him to ‘follow me around...”
(into the phone) Right now, the Washington Post is in bed, asleep... And Gary Hart is in a locked room with his entire campaign team, figuring a way out of this.
He’s not wrong.

You have twenty minute to make tomorrow’s Al. (adding) No quote. EXT. DIXON’S APARTMENT, DENVER - NIGHT Dixon exits the front door and approaches a waiting car. clearly got packed in two minutes. He hops in the passeng seat. Irene Kelly is behind the wheel. They start driving
Are we...?
I don’t know.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 75.
Lights flip on as Emerson enters to find Sweeney already manning a phone at a desk. Nearby, STACKS OF HART POSTERS

(into the phone) Tell Fiedler we can give him an interview with the girl. Straighten everything out. Just buy us some time. Sweeney opens a bottle of whiskey takes a deep inhale, th drinks a glass of water. Emerson just swigs the whiskey.

location: QUALITY INN GUEST ROOM, CAPITOL HILL

text: The phone rings. Murphy picks up with an informal greetin He mutes the receiver under his arm and turns to Fiedler.
They say the girl will talk to us.

(shakes his head) They’re stalling. INT. AIRPLANE, DENVER. MIDNIGHT. Dixon, Shore and Kelly out of breath as they board a flig The last two people aboard. The flight attendant gives a little look - You made it - the captain is finishing his pre-flight announcement. INT. BROADHURST’S KITCHEN, CAPITOL HILL. CONTINUOUS. Billy B hangs up his phone. He turns to Donna.
They don’t want to hear my side of things?
They don’t care. Fuckers are going to print without sources.
Can I talk to Gary? PRELAP: The jarring ring of an old phone...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 76.
We hear the phone ringing.
We see Andrea shuffle in to pick up the phone.
(groggy) Hello?
Hey kiddo, I need you to get your mother for me.
Dad, it’s the middle of the night. Is everything okay...?
Andrea. Andrea stops short. Lee enters in night clothes and takes phone from her daughter.
Hello? There’s a pause and then...
Something’s happened.
All right. What is it? INT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE, CAPITOL HILL. CONTINUOUS. Hart sits at the kitchen island, eyes closed, phone to hi ear. He rolls the glass of VODKA on the counter.
There’s going to be a story. Tomorrow. About me. A long beat. Lee sighs.
What they’re going to write... shouldn't ever be written. I can’t seem to stop them...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 77.
(exasperated) Oh, just say it, Gary.
I met a woman in Miami. They followed her. To DC. To our townhouse in DC.
I see. A long beat as Lee absorbs the pain. We see Andrea watchi her mother with anxious curiosity.
The one thing I ever really asked is that you don’t embarrass me. Hart nods painfully.
I feel so stupid.
Good. Sounds like you should. Feel stupid for a while. And with that, she hangs up.

A hand grabs the POST, still inside the wet newspaper bag INT. BROADHURST’S LIVING ROOM, CAPITOL HILL - MORNING Broadhurst enters, opening up the paper. He finds Dixon watching Donna from the kitchen. She sits on a sofa with lost gaze. There’s a nod between both men before Dixon le to find a seat across from Donna, watching her like an investigative journalist.
What are you doing here, Donna?
I don’t know. I just want to go home. Can I go home now?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 78.
Sure, of course. Soon. I know you want to get home. Broadhurst walks through the background leafing through t Post, not finding anything of note.
I don’t belong here.
I just need to know the facts.
Talk to Gary.
Gary's not a big talker when it comes to... this kind of thing.
I told you already.
Uh-huh.
I wanted a job with the campaign. BB arranged the interview.
(has to smile) An interview? Quick POP of Broadhurst and Armandt sitting nearby. He lo miserable and guilty. Armandt reads the Post.
You've worked in politics before, Donna?
No. I just wanted to work for Senator Hart.
Why’s that?
I like his positions. Dixon smirks.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 79.
You think I’m some stupid bimbo.
I don’t think anything.
I sell pharmaceuticals, you know.
Ok.
I was the top saleswoman in my district.
I don’t doubt it.
I graduated Phi Betta Kappa... I did all the things I was supposed to do to make sure men didn’t look at me the way you’re looking at me right now. All Dixon can do is sigh.
I need to get home.

Yeah. Let me see how we’re doing with that. Dixon rises wearily. We TRACK HIM as he walks to THE KITC where Irene Kelly stands in the doorway. She’s been watch Dixon talk to Donna and clearly has mixed feelings. Shore at the table, underlining passages on crinkly fax paper.
The Herald piece just came across.
Already?
Didn't exactly wait for comment.
Gary see it?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 80.
We moved him to Georgetown. Steve and Kitty's.
(shakes his head) «+. Who he should have fucking been with at the derby. (turns to Irene Kelly) OK. Your turn. Kelly looks to Dixon. She wasn’t expecting this.

Shouldn’t take much. Kelly nods. A complicated look on her face. INT. WASHINGTON POST NEWSROOM. CONTINUOUS. Close up on a TELETYPE as it slowly spits out a headline. It’s the Herald story: “Miami Woman Linked to Hart” and t image of Hart in his hoodie below it. A hand grabs the sheet just as the next one starts to eme from the machine. It’s Ann Devroy. She turns to somebody.

You seen Parker? INT. STEVE MOSES’S STUDY, GEORGETOWN. LATE SUNDAY MORNING We find Hart sitting behind an antique desk, unsettled an beat up, reading through a sheaf of paper. Then a KNOCK on the door jamb and the sound of bags being dropped on the floor as Dixon and Shore enter.
How you holding up?

(clearly shaken) When we talk about a digitized economy, I wonder if we have to talk more about equality of opportunity. Dixon, confused, looks over at the nearby couch where Wil and Stratton sit. The three aides exchange ‘are we really talking about this?’ looks. Dixon takes a deep breath.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 81.
We can’t hide from this, Gary.
Who's hiding? I’m working.
.+. We need to say something.
I’ve already spoken to the person that matters.
There are stories being written. Right now.
It’s gossip, Dix. It’1l blow over.
I don’t think it’s blowing over. Hart’s still looking down at his remarks. Gary..
We need to go through some things. This boat cruise I’m hearing about, for one, and --
Do we think they completely missed the back door of the townhouse?
It’s not in the piece. They must not have checked.
If they don’t have her leaving...
Without the back door, the entire article amounts to -
- Garbage. Come to think, I don’t remember many alleyways in Florida.
Of course. Florida developed after the industrial revolution. No horse and carriage. It is a primarily front door community...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 82.
Gary...
Forget the fucking back door! The point is it’s nobody’s goddamn business. None of it is. They shouldn't have been there, period. (beat) Now, if we can all move on.
That's what we’re trying to do.
I've been doing this for 20 years. So have you. The public doesn’t care about this crap. They won’t stand for it.
This isn’t ‘72. It’s not even ‘82. It’s different now. I don’t know why, but it is. If we get our story down, we can --
There is no story! They can write all this crap all they want, but they will not earn the dignity of my response!
Jesus, Gary. How about us? Do we deserve a response?
About this? No. Shore and Wilson look like kids whose parents are fightin

I’ve got a hundred kids unpacking boxes back in Denver right now because we told them you would do what it took to win. I told them! The best and the brightest. They left families and jobs. Billy left his fiance --
She left me --  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 83.
People are sacrificing for you.

I’m not sacrificing? Should I sacrifice my privacy? My self- respect? It won’t just be me who gets dragged down. None of those kids you’re talking about will ever work another campaign where some candidate doesn’t have to account for who comes and goes from their bedroom. And that’s just the beginning.

We're not talking about that. Future campaigns, at the moment, are not our responsibility. We’re talking about how you get through today without pissing away everything we’ve worked for on this campaign!
This campaign is about the future, not rumors and sleaze. I care about the sanctity of this process whether you do or do not. And he’s finished. Dixon pauses. Watching.

(to Wilson) I want to reexamine the language on page 17. It’s not just the specter of a trade war I worry about. It’s the loss of influence globally. OFF Shore and Dixon's looks. INT. BROADHURST’S LIVING ROOM, CAPITOL HILL. CONTINUOUS. Irene Kelly and Donna sit at the coffee table.
(holding up a coffee) You sure you don’t want any?
Tea?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 84.
(over her shoulder) Can you make a hot tea?
Yes ma’am.
Why did Lynn get to leave?
Because I’m not sure you can trust her. And I don’t.
You're kidding. Lynn?
I don’t know.
Why were they interrogating me?
The standard practice for a scandal is to get all the damaging facts out yourself - If there are any. So it doesn't look like you're hiding.
But you’ll keep me out of it? My parents won’t hear about any of this, will they?
We know what we’re doing.
BB did say you might have a job for me. Fundraising? I graduated magna cum laude.
That’s impressive.
Do you believe it? About a job?
You sound pretty qualified.
It’s just, when you're a model, you know. People just assume.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 85.
That you can’t be smart.
Right.
(smiles) I don’t have that problem.
No! I wasn’t comparing.
Kidding. I mean, I don't have that problem. But I get why you do.
(from the kitchen) Honey in it, honey? Kelly looks at Donna, who shrugs.
Southern Comfort! Donna’s eyes widen and she actually laughs.
Well all right then! INT. BEN BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - AFTERNOON Editors and reporters, in weekend clothes, are gathered. TV, a news reporter. Logo reads - “FOLLOW ME AROUND.”
They're using my quote.
(shrugging) Congrats.
It’s completely out of context.
What context? The only context is that the idiot says “follow me around” and then goes and fucks his mistress on Capitol Hill.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 86.
It was a throwaway line. They’re using it after the fact to justify some tabloid bullshit.
Would we have staked him out? If we knew about the girl?
I hope not.
So you get to decide which lies matter and which lies don’t!

All right, all right, enough! The kid's right. They're just covering their asses. (lost in a memory) So help me this is true. That New Years Eve after Jack died, Lyndon Johnson sits down with a bunch of us, pulls us in close and says, ‘Boys? You’re gonna see some girls come in and out of my hotel suites, and I want you to give me the same courtesy you gave Jack.’ Just like that. And we did. We did, goddamnit.
Different time, Ben.
Why? Who decides that?
The readers.
And if the readers want to see the candidates naked?
Well, that’s one kind of measuring contest.
What is the limit to our curiosity?
Where is he?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 87.
Hart’s gone into hiding. Sweeney won’t tell me where. He’s got a big econ speech Tuesday in NY with the newspaper association.
(chuckling) The publishers...
Iran-Contra hearings start this week? Can’t make this shit up.
It’s a big speech. First major policy address since he announced.
Policy? Is he serious?
All right. Suppose we do something small. Write something up from the wires about the Herald’s little expose.
Are we going after Hart or the Herald? Before anyone can answer...

Lee grinds coffee as the radio plays Travis Tritt, surprisingly LOUD, like she’s trying to drown out the wor She HEARS something in the distance, under the music. She turns off the music and we HEAR it. A LOUD RUMBLING combined with a PIERCING WHINE. She stops what she’s doin walks to the front of the house and steps out onto the screened in porch.

Mom? Lee doesn’t answer, but we SEE what she sees: A massive SATELLITE TRUCK sits at the front gate. Couple VANS sit nearby. DIESEL GENERATORS and PNEUMATIC PUMPS sending loud whines into the sky.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 88. REPORTERS, PRODUCERS, ENGINEERS mill around the gate, unpacking equipment. It’s like an invading army. Lee simply reenters the house, walks back into the kitche
Mom, what’s happening?
It’s an invasion.
I don’t understand. INT. HART CAMPAIGN HEADQUARTERS, DENVER. AN HOUR LATER.

(on his phone, pacing) Maureen! Listen to what I’m telling you! They were hiding in the bushes, OK? Like fucking scavengers. Is that journalism? Behind him, a chaotic scene with phones RINGING constantl We see STAFFERS answering questions. Joe (former owner of Brainy Smurf) shuffles up and motion Sweeney that he has another call.
Mrs. Hart. On four.

Maureen, I gotta go. Please do me a favor and ask your editors to remember they run the New York Fucking Times, OK? Not US Weekly. (beat) Oh, that’s funny. You’re hilarious. Sweeney SLAMS the phone down. He’s about to pick up Lee o line four when he makes eye contact with Emerson.
You don’t think he actually...?

(to Joe Trippi) You got a car? Trippi doesn’t. Sweeney tosses him his keys. Takes a deep breath, then picks up the phone.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 89. EXT. HART CABIN, TROUBLESOME GULCH. SUNDAY DUSK. An old JEEP WRANGLER barrels up the gravel road, past a l of five or six SAT VANS. It screeches to a halt outside the front gate, kicking up cloud of dust. Joe Trippi gets out and gawks at the truck He turns around and nearly slams into a boom mic. A pack REPORTERS close in on him.
Who are you?
Are you with the Hart campaign?
I’ve, uh, got no comment for you. I’m sorry.
When is Lee coming out? Will there be a statement? A slick reporter approaches, camera already rolling.
Hello young man, Steve Dunleavy. A Current Affair. Who are you going to see in there?

(bewildered) A Current Affair? Trippi continues, finally getting through the gate. He’s about to keep walking when he spots a TABLOID PHOTOGRAPHE in an old OAK TREE, trying to get an angle into the cabin
Hey! What the fuck? Get down from there!

head_text.subj: INT. HART CABIN, TROUBLESOME GULCH. MOMENTS LATER

text: Lee Hart answers the door for Trippi.
Hi, Joe Trippi ma'am. Here to help.
Okay, what’s your plan?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 90. Joe goes to speak, but has nothing. Lee smiles.

location: CHECK IN DESK, DULLES AIRPORT HOTEL

text: Irene steps away from the desk with a room key to find Do lost in thought.
It’s only one night. Donna nods, sullenly.
I saw a bar. INT. “WHEELS UP” BAR, DULLES AIRPORT HOTEL - LATER End of the bar. Empty glasses beginning to stack.
That’s my one time in Miami! Shit- faced, lost and bumming a ride off some lecherous guy I knew I’d never see again!
Guys in Miami... One of my ex- boyfriends had his car repo’d while we were at the movies.
Seriously?
I still can’t see Indiana Jones without picturing Ed Clausen crying in the parking lot. (they laugh) Another’s in jail for selling blow.
Jesus.
Yeah. Even my mom doesn’t know about that. Donna nods in agreement as the WAITER sets down 2 more be
Gary's so different.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 91. Kelly flinches at the sound of his name, but hides it.
How so?
He asks about me. Even if nothing comes of it. I feel like I can just be quiet with him. Myself. You ever have that feeling?
Did the Senat... Gary know you were a model? Did you show him pictures?
Oh God, no. Don’t get the wrong idea. I do tasteful shoots. Toothpaste. Jeans.
You don’t...?

No! (long beat) I mean... One time, during a shoot, a photographer I thought was a friend of mine talked me into posing with nothing but an American flag. Patriotism, you know. And when I saw them later... (quieter) My boob was hanging out.
Some friend!
Right? I was so mad. I’m way more selective now. You have to be smart.
You are.
Thank you. Coming from someone like you. I mean. Look at where you are. Beat as Kelly takes a drink, looking at Donna.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 92.

I’m sorry you got caught up in this, Donna. This whole world we’re in. None of it’s making sense right now. You should be somewhere else. EXT. OUTSIDE THE MOSES HOME, GEORGETOWN. SUNDAY NIGHT. Dixon, carrying his bag, stands with Shore on the sidewal
It has to mean something, right? If she swears it was a job interview. Dixon's looks off, down the street, watching something, l in thought.

I’ve known Gary a long time. In '84 we were in this hotel, I forget which one. Me and Gary and Warren Beatty. And Gary starts wigging out because now, you know, he might actually win the thing, and he’s grilling the Secret Service agents. (as Hart) ‘What if I’m president and I want to fly to Boulder for the day and shop for used books with my kids? What about my private time?’ And Warren goes, ‘Gary, you’re not getting it. There is no privacy. The cameras go everywhere now.’ A cab pulls up. Dixon waves to the driver.
Gary’s confounded. ‘That’s Hollywood, Warren. That’s the paparazzi. That’s not politics.’

He’s right, isn’t he? We SEE what Dixon’s been looking at -- a FEMALE REPORTER a notebook a few houses down, knocking on doors, a camera waiting behind her. They’re closing in. Dixon opens the cab door.

I don’t know. Is he?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 93. PRELAP: the sound of A WHIRRING CHOPPER. INT. FRONT PORCH, TROUBLESOME GULCH. MONDAY MORNING. Trippi, sprawled on a wicker couch with a blanket, stirs awake from the sound of the choppers close overhead, he r and goes to the screen door. In the distance, A MOB OF REPORTERS are setting up their stakeout equipment for the day and drinking coffee outsid the front gate like they own the place. INT. HART KITCHEN, TROUBLESOME GULCH. CONTINUOUS. Trippi shuffles in groggily and sees Lee at the stove, he back turned to him. Andrea’s at the farmhouse-style table
Were you able to sleep? Lee just gives him a look and slides some scrambled eggs his plate. Andrea has her head in a cup of coffee. A rota phone is RINGING harshly. The RINGING stops.
You could take that off the hook.
It’s unlisted. Not many people have the number. (beat while he eats) Jesse Jackson called.
Really?
Just told me to keep my chin up. He’s a lovely man. Strange. Lee takes another look through the window. She observes t news vans and journalists camped out at her gate.
All these people want to feel anger and outrage for me, but it doesn’t belong to them. It’s my anger. They can’t have it.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 94,
It, er, it won’t be easy getting out that gate.
We'll figure it out. I think I’1l be ready to fly soon.
What?
I need to see my husband.
Mom. Seriously?
I've spent thirty years of my life with your father. I’ve made many allowances... Lee sees the disappointment in her daughter's eyes.
You think I should feel humiliated. Trippi and Andrea say nothing.
Feelings that simple are a privilege of being young. Our marriage is complicated. So is our love for one another. (to Trippi) You married, Joe?
Yes, ma’am. Just last year.
I think you’1l find that it’s more complex than what they said at the altar.
You should let him deal with this.
He will.
But you’re just letting him off the hook!  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 95.
(a sharp look) Andrea... I went to a Nazarene College. We invented penance.
As they approach the ESCALATOR to the land side, Kelly ta Donna’s arm and stops her. Passengers continue to stream
We've got a car waiting downstairs. It’ll take you wherever you need.
Thank you.
And we've got a guy here in Miami. A lawyer who can --
Thank you, but I just want --
Let me just give you his number.

Really, Irene. I don’t know what I'd have done without you. But I just want to get home. She hugs Kelly quickly and turns to descend an escalator the baggage claim area. She’s having a moment to herself. first in a while, when suddenly - A CAMERA FLASH. Below, we see a gathering mob. The questions are aggressi
Donna! Donna Rice! Look up here, please!
(bewildered) How do you know my name?
Are you and Gary in love?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 96.
In love? How did you...?
Was your boyfriend a drug Do you have ties to the drug dealer? trade?
No... I don’t know what you’re talking about.
Was the boat really called Monkey Business?
(recoiling and shaking) I’m just... Just trying to go home.

What kind of erotic pictures can we expect to find from you? Donna looks back for Kelly, tears swelling. She can barel see her walking away. Donna turns back around. She looks frightened and shattered. The shouts of her name continue build as we suddenly...
As a secretary, you saw your boss shredding documents... Reveal, we're at an...

Irene Kelly sips a much needed drink. Half watching Fawn testify about Oliver North on television. INT. BEN BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST. DAY. A TELEVISION plays the same hearing. We PULL OUT to find Bradlee, Devroy, Kaiser, and Broder watching the hearing with fascination.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 97. A CLERK taps on the door frame. He’s holding a PADDED ENVELOPE. No one hears him amongst the ad-libbed response Hall’s testimony. He knocks a little louder. Broder sees him and points to the desk. The clerk sets it down on Bradlee’s heavy desk. He hangs back for a moment.
What, are you waiting for a tip? The clerk scurries off.
Wilson and Shore are having a drink. The TONIGHT SHOW lea plays on an old TV.
Next up, Johnny's got George C. Scott and gymnast Kristie Phillips!
Something’s been bothering me. (off Shore’s look) I mean, he sees the entire chessboard at all times. He looks at the country and see decades ahead of anyone. How the hell did he not see this coming?
He’d say - It's Chinatown, Jake. (off Wilson's look) It’s just fucked.
Are we just spinning our wheels? When do we know we’re dead?
We had a dinner at Sorenson’s place tonight. Raised four hundred thousand dollars. Wilson takes this positive news in. We see him visibly re
...the Tonight Show with Johnny Carson! And heeeer’s Johnny! We hear the familiar opening music in the background.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 98.
(from actual footage) By the way, before the monologue begins. If Gary Hart is watching, you might want to hit the mute button on your remote control. Wilson and Shore share a look of death.
Hart’s lying on the bed in his undershirt. He’s reading through his speech while making notes on a legal pad. The is on in the background.

I really don't need a monologue tonight. I'll just bring out and read the front pages of newspapers around the country. It is getting so wild that people standing in supermarkets are rushing out to buy regular newspapers. Hart puts down his notes and grabs the remote to turn it

USA Today is advertising numbers to call. It's kind of a poll. You can call in an 800 number, one number, if you think the press coverage has been fair. There's another 800 number you call if you think it's been unfair. And there's a third 800 number to call if you want to meet Donna Rice. Loud laughter and hooting... And then ZAP -- Carson disappears and the screen goes black. Hart’s holding the remote, frozen. He picks up a LEGAL PA INT./EXT. TOWN CAR, MANHATTAN. NEXT MORNING. Hart’s in the back seat, going over his speech throughout Stratton’s in the front passenger seat, next to Shore beh the wheel.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 99.
(distracted) Left. Rusting industrial base... deteriorating public infrastructure... declining system of public education... astounding accumulation of public and private debt...
On 49th?
We’re going in the front.
Has Dix seen what they’ve got?
You sure?
Right up there...
Billy?
Dix hasn't been back to the office. The car is slowing to a stop outside the hotel. FLASH...

You’ve called him? Before Shore can answer... WHAM! - A BODY sprawls onto th windshield. FLASH! - The photog on the hood clicks away. FLASH, FLASH, FLASH. PAPARAZZI surround the car and BANG against the windows.
Jesus! Stratton jumps out and pulls the photographer off the hoo the car, before hopping back in. STRATTON (CONT’D) Go! Gol
Go where?!  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 100.
Pull away! I can’t pull away! I’11 kill somebody!
(opening his door) Get out of the car! Let’s go! Shore opens his door and Stratton comes around, pulling a deeply rattled Hart from the car. Stratton pushes his way through the scrum to the car.

This way! C’mon! They guide Hart through the throng of SHOUTING, SHOVING PHOTOGRAPHERS toward the front door of the Waldorf Astori INT. GRAND BALLROOM, WALDORF ASTORIA. 10 MINUTES LATER. Hart still rattled by the attack outside, sits on the dai next to Senator BOB DOLE. The room buzzes with anticipati An EMCEE gives a dry introduction in the background.
So.... How was your weekend, Gary? Dole cracks a smile. Hart laughs despite himself. Something in the balcony catches his attention. He shades eyes and peers into the lights.
Is that Tom?
Huh?
Brokaw. Is that Brokaw? Here? The lens reaches into the balcony to SEE TOM BROKAW and h crew frantically setting up in the balcony, which is pack elbow-to-elbow with reporters and cameras.
(droll) Guess they’re really curious about your economics plan. Hart shakes his head.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 101.

Hell of a deal, Gary. Hell of a deal. Hart looks around the room. He notices MARTINDALE sitting down along the dais. He pulls his speech from his pocket begins to scribble further. We move up into the BALCONY. Parker sits among a group of reporters on the risers where the cameras are set up. He clocks Hart jotting notes.
(re: something else) Jesus, that’s balls.
Huh? McDaniel nods to a place across the risers, where Fiedler standing alone.
Front row seats. Back ON STAGE, we find Shore in the wings. Weinberg, the reporter from the beginning of the film approaches.
Billy Shore. You hear Stevie Wonder won’t play Arizona until they recognize Martin Luther King Day?
Nothing to announce, Alan.
(smiles) I‘ll keep asking.

head_text.subj: INT. GRAND BALLROOM, WALDORF ASTORIA. 20 MINUTES LATER.

text: Two rows of suit-n-tied men are on the dais. Hart is now speaking at the podium.
Good afternoon. Thank you. I’m here today to talk to you about America’s future. That’s what my campaign is and ought to be about. (MORE )

But with your permission, I'd like to address the events of the last three days that you have no doubt been discussing amongst yourselves. Quick shot of Parker, riveted. Others amongst the press leaning in. Lenses ZOOMING.

Last weekend, a newspaper published a misleading story that hurt my family and reflected badly upon my character. Quick shot of Fiedler, soaking in his Watergate moment. HART (CONT’D) This story was written by reporters who by their own admission, undertook a spotty surveillance... We catch MARTINDALE from the Miami Herald along one of th arms of the DAIS. He rolls his eyes and whispers loudly..
Jesus Christ, man the lifeboats...

What was that? A frozen beat between the two of them. Martindale gives a and a gesture - keep going, you're doing fine on your own HART (CONT’D) Something you'd like to say? We see Shore and Stratton at one of the tables on the flo
Fuck. What do we? I can yell fire.
He’s got this. Back to Hart. Unmoving.
Is there something you’d like to ask me? Or does the Miami Herald prefer to chat in alleyways? Light laughter.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 103.
(speaking loudly) Senator, this is not a story about the Miami Herald. This is a story about Gary Hart's judgment.
Can we get him... (aside) Can we get him a microphone? Staffers move a CABLED MICROPHONE to Martindale.
(now on mic) We stand by the essential correctness of our story.
The essential correctness? More laughter from the audience.
This is a story about a married man who spent a considerable amount of time with an unmarried woman. We’ve never speculated on what went on...
If I may, it’s because you simply don’t know... Despite hiding in the bushes outside my home. We briefly find Fiedler in the audience.
(quietly) I wasn’t in his fucking bushes.
We know you called Donna Rice several times from the campaign trail. We know she was seen leaving your town house in Washington...
Well was she leaving or not? In your story she didn’t leave my home. Now, you’re saying she did.
Senator, when we interviewed you...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 104.
Your newsmen accosted me in my alleyway. Some interview.
With all due respect...

It’s a little late for respect, sir. You ambushed me outside my home in the middle of the night after putting me under some half- baked stake out... During which, your crack reporting team failed to realize my home had a back door.
(you're going with that?) A back door?
Some surveillance is no better than zero surveillance. In fact, it’s worse.
You do your job, we’ll do ours.
It would be a welcome change. Martindale throws his hands in exasperation. Meanwhile Pa furiously takes notes.

Now if no one else minds, I’d like to discuss something a little more exciting. Economics. LAUGHTER as we close in on Fiedler, also taking notes, wh FLASH suddenly distracts him. Fiedler looks up to see a photographer snapping away at h He looks around and notices other journalists taking note him. He’s become part of the story and he doesn’t like it
The HART CAMPAIGN BUS works its way up a hill.
Hart, Shore, and Sweeney huddle around a table as staffer work furiously around them. A staffer is passing out sandwiches to the men. There’s a of ad-libbed confusion over who ordered what.
Back to New Hampshire.
Live free or die.
Wonder how many people pick “die”?
I can’t keep answering these questions.
One more presser. We let them ask whatever they want and we put it to bed. Get back to big ideas.
Well, you have conceded that you weren’t able to watch the back of his townhouse...
Footage of Ted Koppel interviewing Tom Fiedler.
... And that, therefore, the lady in question may have left when you thought she was still there.
(sweating and stammering) Well, that’s, um... That’s... I mean, Mr. Koppel. Ted... (MORE )
If we’re conceding that we’re not as good as the FBI at conducting surveillance, then I think we have no problem agreeing to that. But --
Hold on. That’s cute, but that’s not the point. Did she spend the night with him or didn’t she spend the night with him?
Right. Well, not right. I mean, the basis of our report was that Senator Hart had this ongoing relationship with this woman who, again, was not his wife. A single woman...
You have spoken several times, Mr. Fiedler, about the relationship. And of course, relationship is one of those loaded words that suggests that somehow there’s been a tryst going on.
No. No, I...I...I haven’t suggested, you know --
Well you've suggested it. You haven't said it, but you’ve certainly suggested it.
(flailing) I think a relationship simply means there were, you know, dealings between two people. There were --
Well you're not suggesting a professional relationship. You were suggesting a romantic relationship.
Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 107. SONY TRINITRON TV - SHOWING “NIGHTLINE”
Well. No. I, uh, I guess we mean a, you know, non-political relationship. Koppel is not impressed.

I can imagine what it’s like, because I’m a reporter too and I’ve been in similar situations. Let me put to you an alternative question. This wasn’t a competitive story. Nobody was breathing down your neck. You could have waited twenty fours hours... and got it right.
(dumbfounded) I believe we did get it right.

Is this a story that the Miami Herald drops now? Fiedler looks at Koppel. Doesn’t feel like Watergate. REV INT. BEN BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST. EVENING.
