The sound from the TV fades into the BG. Parker is watchi with a big grin, when he notices the rest of the office h focused on something else. Bradlee is leafing through photos from the PADDED ENVELOP revealed earlier. Kaiser, Broder, and Devroy are experien a collective emotional kidney stone.
Fuck me. Close the blinds, would you?
I know this broad. Broad? - Devroy shoots a look to Broder.
(holding out a pack) Gum?  Who? Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 108.
Yeah, she’s a lobbyist.
(to Kaiser) No, thanks.
Run me through this again.
They’re part of a PI report. A certain Senator thought his wife was sleeping with Hart.
Jesus, this guy...
We're thinking Tydings...

But as it turns out, Hart isn’t fucking Mrs. Tydings. He’s been schtupping this other woman. We SEE a few photos up close - A smart looking political woman is EMBRACING Hart and letting him into her house.
What a town.
How did we get this?
Anonymous package.
I hate those. You got something to say - Say it. (to Kaiser) Give me some of that gum.
You think Tydings sent it?
But why?
Are we going to even talk about Bush? Hart’s running against the former head of the CIA.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 109.
Not yet, he’s not.
No return address, no note. Just a date. Six months ago.
Well there’s your other shoe, Ben.
Yup.
I mean, just because an unmarked envelope lands in our laps. That doesn’t obligate us to...
It’s a pattern of behavior. Womanizing. Lies.
He’s not lying to us.
Christ, don’t be so naive.
I have no doubt the same envelope probably landed in the laps of three other enterprising reporters.
Okay, I mean, can’t we let some other paper run gossip as front page news. Doesn’t mean we...

But it does, AJ. It does now. (professorial) We decline to publish, and then some other pissant paper runs with it anyway... I don’t know, the Poughkeepsie Journal... or the Miami Herald... or the New York Times... And the TVs go fucking apeshit over the story. And we get on our high horse and say, well we still don't think it's news, because after all we didn’t think it was news before, right? (MORE )

And now the wires are running a story about how we won’t cover the only thing anyone in the entire country is talking about, and, so on and so on. A beat of silence. Bradlee looks to Broder - What do you think...? Broder shakes his head - no.
Parker walks up to find Devroy making coffee by herself.
Why do you hate him so much?
I don’t hate Gary Hart. I don’t think I trust him...
That’s one approach.
That’s my job.
To pass judgement?
To be skeptical. I don’t think his own wife trusts him. Why should I?
I think you should trust him on the things that matter.
Okay, I question his respect for women.
Are you kidding me? He loves women. Too much, frankly...
He uses them.
Aren’t we being a little precious here? He’s smart and handsome and these women are throwing themselves at him...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) lll.

He’s a man with power and opportunity and that takes a certain responsibility. If he was some day trader screwing cocktail girls, I could handle just not liking him... but as our potential next president, as a woman, that makes me nervous... And as a journalist, you should care.
I think you’re being a little sensitive.
Oh, fuck you. You know what name I'd like to hear Gary Hart say? Donna Rice.
(combative) What exactly is he supposed to say?

I don’t know. I’m not running for president. He is. And now we get to see what he does when he’s under pressure. He throws a woman under the campaign bus. Devroy leaves with her coffee. A nearby clerk motions for Parker’s attention.

We find Irene Kelly, subdued, inside a phone booth. Diali number. It’s late. A hotel worker vacuums. Intercut with INT. BILL DIXON’S APARTMENT - NIGHT The phone is ringing. We turn to see Dixon in his favorit chair, watching the BASEBALL GAME. He ignores the incomin call for a long time, then finally lifts the receiver.
Yeah?
You're missing all the excitement.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17)
(a beat) Thank God.
Looks like we’re turning the corner out here. I could get you a flight. Dixon has no response. Perhaps Kelly expected that.
What’s on your mind?

I just keep thinking... This is never going to be over for her. Every time she applies for a job... She doesn’t have a staff of overeducated volunteers. As far as I can tell, she’s alone. A long pause.
You got anything for me? Dixon thinks. He can’t tell her that she’s wrong.
Buck up kid. You’ve got work to do. Kelly nods. Sucks it up.
Hart, stripped to his sleeveless undershirt and still in pants, is doing push-ups. Sweat beads on his face and he huffs. We watch him do a couple.
They don’t have a podium.
I don’t need one.
(to Stratton) You couldn't get a podium?
Don’t start with me.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 113.
How're voters supposed to believe you?! You've clearly been lying!
They will or they won't. I don’t think they much care. We SEE Shore sitting in plush chairs nearby, sipping a Co Sweeney is pacing. Hart pops up.
(friendly again) You can cite the polls here.
I don’t care about polls.

(finishing each other's thoughts ) Yes you do. Gallup just came out of the field - Do you think the media went too far in its reporting on Senator Hart's private life? 64 percent say yes. Do you think a candidate's behavior in his Marriage is relevant to his qualifications as president? 38 percent say yes. 52 percent no.
Take that, fuckers.
64 percent. Got it.
(quietly to Shore) They’1l ask about phone calls.
Uh-huh. I call lots of people.
Right. That’s fine.
Are we going to bring up Donna Rice? The mention of her name chills the room.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 114.
We could ask the pool to respect her privacy?
Are you fucking nuts?
It could be seen as a noble gesture. Kelly looks to Hart for a response, but gets nothing.
(to Hart) They may ask you about, you know... Women.
They can talk to Irene or Ginny. Anyone who’s worked for me...
Yeah, I think what Billy means... Have there been others. Women that aren't... your wife.
(turning quickly) Now you have got to be kidding me! I’m not going to answer that! Not for them and not for you! That’s nobody's goddamn business!
That's it! That’s perfect. That’s your answer. There’s a knock at the door. It opens, revealing LEE HART The team quickly begins gathering their things to leave.
I’'1l come back when it’s time. The door closes behind them, leaving just Gary and Lee. H sitting on the edge of the bed, unsure whether to move. Lee walks to the window.
I... I’m sorry... I...  Hart bows Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 115.
I’ve woken up the last two mornings to the sound of helicopters. They're waiting at our gates. Dozens of them. Trucks with satellites. Their trash littered all over our driveway.
How’s Andrea?
She's disappointed. his head in shame.

(stoic) Just to leave our home, She had to climb in the back seat. One of your staffers threw an old blanket over our daughter. That’s how she left our house. Hiding like a criminal. Like she should be ashamed.
(stumbling) These people should be ashamed... (adding) The public won’t stand for it.
(staring out the window) Right.
Lee... I’m so sorry.
I can imagine. Sorry you got yourself in this mess. (scoffs) I’m sorry too. Gary wants to apologize but doesn’t know how.
I feel so foolish.
Maybe I’m the foolish one. I gave you all that rope and then I tripped over it.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 116. Lee begins walking to Gary.

Were you thinking of me when you were flirting with this girl? Were you thinking of me on that boat when you were making her laugh in front of fifty other people? Were you thinking of me when you invited her into our home? Gary shakes his head then drops it. A long beat.
Are you leaving me?
I didn’t fly across the country just to say goodbye. That’s what phones are for.
You think you can you accept my apology?

Not right now - Not yet - Maybe at some point. And that might feel like a burden. It should. You hurt me... and you need to know that. You need to feel it. Carry it so I don’t have to. (a beat) There'll be a time for us to talk about why you did this and why I should ever trust you again. But that will have to wait. When it’s just the two of us. Lee now standing before him as he sits hunched on the bed reaches out and wraps his arms around her torso, hugging She rests her hands on his shoulders.
Devroy is working with a LAYOUT EDITOR at a LIGHT TABLE.
If we push the girl scout diamond anniversary to page three, we'll have to lose the picture.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 117.
Fuck. I liked the picture. Is this to make room for the tank piece? Bradlee wanders in.
(to Layout) Find a way to save the girl scouts. Bradlee and Devroy begin moving copy on the light table absentmindedly as they discuss the following.
At some point we need to draw a line in the sand. We might not agree where that line is...
Where does honesty fall?
Ask a man enough questions and you're going to reach a point where he either has to lie or simply refrain from answering, which is kind of the same as lying.
Maybe if he didn’t put himself ina position where he needed to lie.
I’m talking about what’s relevant. Some paper is going to want to know if the president can still get it up or if the first lady still goes down on him...
I’m not asking to know any of that.
But we’re opening a door... I don’t know. Maybe the door’s already open.

I’m a reporter. I can only work with what’s presented to me. I follow leads. I look for the truth. And the truth is he lied to his wife and then he lied to all of us. Is that relevant?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 118. INT. PARKER'S CUBICLE, WASHINGTON POST —- EVENING Bradlee walks by Parker's desk. He drops the ENVELOPE OF PHOTOS with a meaningful look.
You have a train to catch. Puts his hand on Parker’s shoulder and keeps moving.
The news vans have assembled. It’s as bad as we’ve seen i

Shore walks up the staircase to the second floor dining a The place buzzes with anticipation. We find Parker at a t with a NOTEPAD and coffee. At another table, McDaniel, Weinberg, and Shanahan watch Parker with mixed envy.
Follow me.
Can you believe that? He just stumbled into a Pulitzer.
I don’t know.
What don’t you know?
I want my president to be smarter than me, not trying to outsmart me. Broder sits with the older crew - Germond, Broder, Wynman Shore comes walking through and Germond grabs his attenti
Let Gary know we’re around if he wants a drink? With old friends?

The senator is unavailable.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 119. Shore keeps walking. Germond takes in the moment. The oth at the table weigh the feeling of being shut out. Broder stands up and walks over to AJ Parker.
You know you don’t have to do this. Parker looks up in question.

You think you’re the first guy he asked? Off Parker's look, Broder keeps walking. Parker nods. INT. HART’S HOTEL ROOM - MORNING Evidence of Hart having slept on the sofa. Gary and Lee g ready in silence. There’s a distance though they are preparing for battle together. Lee gives her husband a lo She fixes his tie. NEWS about Hart plays on the TV. text: We're in a tight room with no raised platform or podium. stands surrounded by over one hundred sitting journalists photographers. Close enough to bite him. His team leans against the wall along with Lee who stands by Irene Kelly
Doesn't this episode call your judgment as a leader into question?

Yes, I suppose I made some mistakes. But I think judgment, like character, has to be measured in the full context of a career. I think what I’ve undertaken in the Senate, the plans I’ve outlined for the nation, speak to my judgment. I’m not aware of anyone having questioned my integrity as a public servant.

Senator Hart! Senator! Over here!  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 120. We see Stratton, on all fours, trying to body-block the c of reporters from Hart. A quick look at Lee. Smiling and composed. Then we see Pa watching her.
Yes.
You were quoted once as saying you love danger. Is that why you think you put yourself in this position?
(smiling) I don’t love it that much, Jack. LAUGHTER among the press corps. A releasing of tension. Angle on Shore, Sweeney, Wilson exchanging a relieved gla
You said there’s no relationship. Are you willing to take a lie detector test?
I think the voters are a pretty good lie detector test. Broder and Germond chuckling.
Will they believe you?
Well, I think they do. The last poll I saw said that most voters think the Herald was out of line. More than 60 percent, in fact.
64 percent.

When the numbers are in your favor, always be specific. Another chuckle from the group. More shouts for attention HART (CONT’D) (pointing towards Parker) Yes.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 121. Parker and another reporter hesitate, unsure of which one Hart’s pointing to.
Mr. Parker. Go ahead. Parker steadies himself.
(voice quivering) Yes. Senator. Thank you. Good afternoon.
Good afternoon to you, AJ. Glad you could make it.
Yes. Senator, in your speech yesterday you raised the issue of morality. I’d like to, um, ask you what you mean, specifically, by that. I have a series of questions, if you don’t mind.
All right.
When you said you did nothing ‘immoral’, did you mean that you had no sexual relationship with Donna Rice, last weekend or at any other time?
I've said there was no relationship. That’s correct. A pause. Parker continues.
Do you believe that adultery is immoral?
Do I...? Well, yes. I do. Hart’s team grows uncomfortable with where this is going.

Senator. Have you ever committed adultery?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 122. It gets so quiet, we almost hear a GASP in the group. Older reporters shake their heads in disbelief. Lee’s face falls. We can see Sweeney hoping for Hart to come back swinging. Come on... Come on...
(under his breath) Say it... Say it... Hart opens his mouth, but freezes. No sound emerges. He looks to Lee. He looks to his feet.

I...I...I guess I don’t think that’s a fair question. It’s a flinch. The campaign team bows their heads as the goes mad with questions and camera flashes, arms lifting follow up questions. WYMAN, a photographer we recognise from earlier bar scene friend of Hart, makes eye contact with Hart... then goes to taking photos. We see Broder leaving the room. Hart and Lee exchange a look amidst the noise... Too many questions at once. And then quiet.
The Harts and their entourage sit quietly. They’re shell- shocked. For a long moment, no one speaks.
Are we doing the last event? Hart’s rummaging in his suit pocket distractedly.
Supposed to have a Town Hall in Littleton. Hart produces a small blue figurine from his pocket. He examines it in wonder.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17)
What’s that?
I believe it’s called a Smurf.
Brainy Smurf, actually.
A WAITER clears plates from the table where Hart, Lee, Stratton and Wilson are eating.
Kevin's right.
Can I get you folks dessert?
Keep on pushing. It’s early. We take it on the chin and then pack the schedule as tight as we can.
I‘ll take a coffee.
Same here. 123. Shore, The waiter is looking at Gary, who stares straight ahead.
Gary?
Hm?
Coffee? Hart waves off the waiter. MOVE TO the entrance of the restaurant. SWEENEY is return from the bathroom. He’s stopped by PARKER, who is holding now familiar PADDED ENVELOPE.
I need time with the candidate.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 124.
(venom) Are you fucking kidding me?
Something’s come up. I have some questions.
You think anyone’s letting you anywhere near their candidate?
Come on, man...

Oh, and I used to steal beer from the corner deli in high school... I tried coke at Berkley... and I cheated on my girlfriend. Twice. Just to save you the time. Parker starts opening the PADDED ENVELOPE. We move back to the Hart table.
Maybe we move up military reform. Do a big rollout here.
Yeah. It’s just...

(to Gary) I need to call Andrea. I’1l be right back. Shore finds a couple dimes for Lee. Hart kind of nods as we follow Lee to the PAY PHONES on t wall. She begins to dial. Back to Hart and the campaign team. We begin to push on H as the chatter between Shore and Stratton becomes a low whisper. Just noise along with the silverware.
I’m all for shaking more hands. I’m just not sure I can get him anywhere near them just yet.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 125.
Could call Denver, get some (returning) more bodies -- Fresh coffees. On the house.
What if... we booked some TV time. I mean, how long would it take to shoot a 30-minute spot?
Saying what?
Can we pay for that?

Go directly to the voters. Talk about reporters out of control, invasion of privacy. Hart looks to the entrance. He SEES Sweeney and Parker. Sweeney is leafing through PHOTOS. His posture falling. Hart leans towards Irene Kelly for a moment.
Any word from Miami?
How do you mean?
Is she okay?

I don’t know how you want me to answer that. Hart's face tightens. He nods. Registering the guilt. BACK TO Sweeney and Parker. Sweeney now leafing through t photos. His face doesn’t betray his feelings. He looks up

Congratulations. You just became the National Enquirer. You're fifty cents at the register. Back to the campaign team. Their conversation is down to whisper. The noise of the restaurant continues to build.
I’m not sure enough people would see it.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 126.
If the media won’t talk about it...
We'd need a national buy.
Where the hell is Dixon? And then Hart hears LEE on the phone cutting through the rest. He turns to the PAY PHONES. Lee is clearly emotiona Hart stands up and walks over to his wife.
(emotional on the phone) OK, you're home now? And you’re safe? We faintly HEAR Andrea’s voice CRYING as she speaks. Hart slowly cracking.

(on phone) It’s outrageous. They cannot, they will not hound you like this. They shouldn’t be anywhere near you. We will take care of this. Lee’s eyes begin to tear up as Gary pulls her into his ar A family just trying to hold on.

(quietly) Lee. It’s time to go home. We move back to the campaign table. Sweeney is joining th table, but Stratton, Shore, and Wilson have already clock the Harts at the pay phone. It couldn’t be more clear. It’s over. EXT. DRIVEWAY, TROUBLESOME GULCH, COLORADO. MORNING. We SEE the WAGONEER weaving through the NEWS VANS. EXT. HART’S FRONT PORCH, TROUBLESOME GULCH - DAY Trippi pours ice tea for the campaign team as Hart writes notes on a legal pad. Ad-libbed thanks and comments, but mostly quiet. Stratton looks out the side, checking out t helicopters with bewilderment. Shore pulls him away.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 127. Hart pauses. He looks out into the trees - Vast beautiful Colorado. It’s wild and unmistakably American.

You know, when General Lee resigned his commission in the union army to command the confederate forces, he had to leave his house in Washington behind. The campaign team turns to listen. As does Lee, even thou she’s heard this story before. HART (CONT’D) The union informed Lincoln and asked if they should tear it down - Light it on fire, what have you... But Lincoln had a different idea. He told them to bury the confederate soldiers in Lee’s backyard.
Jesus.
That’s how we got Arlington cemetery. Hart looks at his backyard - an infinite run of trees lea to red mountains.
For the first time - Quiet. A couple people answer phones Dixon approaches Terzano. Her eyes are red. He hands her ENVELOPE from a stack. She eyes him quizzically.
(off her look) Cash it before the end of the day. Dixon moves to Bill Martin and hands him an envelope.
PRELAP: the rapid clicking of a hundred camera shutters  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 128.

In public life, somethings may be interesting, but that doesn’t necessarily mean they’re important. Hart is moving down a line of his campaign team, shaking hands. In effect, saying goodbye to them. At 51, he is ab to walk way from public service for the rest of his life. Each good bye carries its own weight - Stratton. Emerson. Wilson. Kelly. Sweeney. Shore.

Hart enters to find Lee waiting for him. He sits across f her. For a moment they just stare at each other. We can t by their body language that this is the beginning of a difficult conversation. What will be the first of many. B we CANNOT hear them. Rather, we give them their privacy. Meanwhile, in the corner on a television, we see Hart at podium with no notes, giving his farewell.
The camera scans the crowd then cuts to Hart at the podiu

Clearly, under present circumstances, this campaign can’t go on. I refuse to submit my family and my friends to further rumors and gossip. It’s an intolerable situation. In the room: Hart reaches for Lee’s hand. On TV: We see a brief moment of Parker watching. HART (ON TV) (CONT’D) But we’re all going to have to seriously question the system for selecting our national leaders that has reporters in bushes and photographers peeking in our windows. That reduces the press of this nation into hunters and the presidential candidates into the hunted. ON TV: As Hart gathers himself, we SEE Kelly, standing wi Shore and Wilson, starting to cry.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 129.

After which, ponderous pundits wonder in mock seriousness why some of the best people in the country choose not to run for high office. Politics in this country is on the verge of becoming another form of athletic competition or sport. We’d all better do something to make this system work, or we’re all going to be soon rephrasing Jefferson to say: I tremble for my country when I think we may, in fact, get the kind of leaders we deserve. The TV goes out of focus. We push in on the Harts as Lee takes Gary’s hands into her own. CUT TO BLACK.
